Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: INVESTIGATING HYDROLOGY-DRIVEN MODELS FOR METHANE CYCLING IN NORTHERN PEATLANDS
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Abstract
A major contributor to the current uncertainty regarding how carbon cycling in peatlands will respond to climate warming is the incomplete understanding of the production, storage and emission of free phase gas (FPG), a previously under-appreciated source of methane and carbon dioxide emissions to the atmosphere. It is increasingly clear that FPG production, storage and emission are regulated by hydraulic forcing, as well as the mechanical properties of the peat, i.e. that the carbon and water cycles in a peatland are intimately connected. The focus of this project is field-scale hydrological and hydrogeophysical research to further investigate the importance of recently invoked "shallow" versus "deep" peat models for the production, storage and emission of FPG in northern peatlands. Specific objectives of the project include [1] quantifying vertical variations in storage and release of methane with depth over a minimum six month time period at each of three locations within a peatland, [2] determining the hydrological forcing mechanisms that drive releases from both deep and shallow gas, [3] estimating spatial variations in storage and release as a function of subsurface heterogeneity, and [4] quantifying relative contributions of shallow versus deep gas to methane emissions from a northern peatland. This research will be conducted by coupling hydrogeological methods with novel chamber, geophysical and geodetic sensing technologies sensitive to FPG production, storage and emissions. The field site is Caribou Bog, a well-studied multi-unit peatland complex in central Maine. Empirical predictive models and simple mechanistic models will be developed to assess the relative importance of key forcing mechanisms on FPG emissions. Time-frequency analysis of time-series datasets will also be employed to improve understanding of likely forcing components regulating production, storage and release of FPG. This research will significantly advance our understanding of hydrological controls on FPG dynamics in northern peatlands, with important implications for the response of peatland carbon dynamics to climate change.

Northern peatlands globally cover more than 350 million ha and contain about one third of the terrestrially stored carbon. The fate of this carbon in response to continued climate warming is highly uncertain. Peatlands are also a source of atmospheric methane, a potent greenhouse gas that contributes to climate warming. This research will provide fundamental scientific knowledge needed to advance the understanding of the cycling of methane in peatlands, and how peatland hydrology controls the emission of methane from peatlands to the atmosphere. The work has direct societal relevance given the concerns about the environmental and economical affects of climate warming. In this project, Lois Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation undergraduate students will be exposed to a hands-on interdisciplinary research among three institutions. Furthermore, an international community of graduate students will participate in a student-focused session on methane cycling in northern peatlands at American Geophysical Union meetings. Community outreach in the vicinity of the Caribou Bog will occur via annual guided tours using the Orono Bog Boardwalk that served +30,000 visitors in 2009.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated methane cycling in a northern peatland using a combination of innovative geophysical and chamber flux measurement techniques. These measurements were primarily focused on improving understanding of the transport and release of free phase gaseous methane from peatlands. The field site was Caribou Bog, an ombotrophic peatland located in central Maine. Field datasets were acquired during three intensive summer campaigns performed during the period July 2011 to August 2013. Supporting laboratory experiments were performed on peat monoliths acquired from multiple locations, defined by vegetation type, within Caribou Bog. The project yielded new insights into the role of atmospheric pressure and pore water pressure as triggers for the release of free phase methane from peatlands. The findings of the project include evidence for a fuzzy threshold of gas content regulating rapid outgassing (ebullition) events. The project captured spatial variability in gas releases from non-invasive subsurface geophysical imaging techniques that avoided disruption of the peat fabric and thus the natural in situ gas regime. The project was a collaboration between Rutgers University Newark, Florida Atlantic University and University of Maine.   

Intellectual Merit: Methane is currently the second most important greenhouse gas regulating the temperature of Earth. Peatlands are the largest natural source of methane to the atmosphere. They are thus important in defining the atmospheric methane burden. Methane is released from peatlands via diffusion, wicking through certain plants and by rapid bursts of free phase gas known as ebullition. The latter process remains relatively poorly quantified due to the difficulties of capturing such free phase gas releases that are highly variable over space and time.  An improved understanding of the mechanisms and patterns of free phase gas release from peatlands is important for predicting how emissions of methane from peatlands will change as the climate warms and/or gets wetter. The measurement strategies adopted in this study advanced understanding of the role of atmospheric pressure and water level variations in regulating short term emissions of free phase gas from peatlands. Measurements were largely acquired with techniques that involved no disruption of the natural peat fabric and gas regime that usually accompanies insertion of probes and sensors. In this work, geophysical imaging techniques were used to monitor subsurface gas dynamics without any disturbance to the natural system. The work resulted in a conceptual model to describe how the peat fabric acts as a valve for gas release based on a balance between buoyancy forces and capillary forces.

Broader Impacts: The findings of this work could be up-scaled to constrain input for the ebullition of free phase gas from wetlands required to calibrate the atmospheric methane burden in global climate models. The project benefitted education and student professional development by providing material for one MS thesis and two PhD dissertations. It also provided unique training and research experiences for four undergraduate minority students from the Garden State Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (GS-LSAMP) program that is run out of Rutgers University Newark.
